action.action-desc: Mr. Engel (for himself and Mr. Welch) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to deny certain tax benefits to persons responsible for the discharge of oil or other hazardous substances into navigable waters of the United States.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Offending Oil Polluters Act.

section.header: Denial of certain tax benefits to offending oil polluters

subsection.text: Subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new part:

part.header: Denial of certain tax benefits to offending oil polluters

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 293. Denial of certain tax benefits to offending oil polluters.

section.header: Denial of certain tax benefits to offending oil polluters

subsection.text: In the case of an offending oil polluter, no deduction or credit shall be allowed under this chapter with respect to any amount paid or incurred—

paragraph.text: in connection with a discharge of oil or a hazardous substance referred to in subsection (b)(1),
for any attorney fees and court costs in connection with any action with respect to such discharge,
as a payment or restitution related to such discharge, and
any costs or penalties required by Federal law or regulations or certified in a settlement by a Federal court.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term offending oil polluter means—

paragraph.text: any person that is a responsible party for a vessel or a facility from which oil or a hazardous substance is discharged (within the meaning of section 311 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1321)), and
any person who is a member of the same expanded affiliated group (as defined in section 1471(e)(2)) as a person described in paragraph (1).

subsection.text: The table of parts for subchapter B of chapter 1 of such Code is amended by adding at the end the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Part XII. Denial of certain tax benefits to offending oil polluters

subsection.text: Not later than 6 months after the date of the enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter, the Secretary of the Treasury (or the Secretary’s delegate) shall conduct a study, and submit the results to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Finance and the Committee on Environment and Public Works of the Senate—

paragraph.text: to determine the loss in revenue to the Treasury as a result of deductions allowed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for cleaning up oil that is discharged (within the meaning of section 1002 of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (33 U.S.C. 2702)) after April 19, 2010, and
to determine the amount of revenue savings by the Treasury as a result of section 293 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (as added by this section).

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2014.
